entry.title: Combined summary - Civ Kit: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Market System
entry.summary: In a recent discussion, Chris and Antoine explored the concept of front-running in a peer-to-peer marketplace. Front-running refers to entering into a trade with advance knowledge of a block transaction that will influence the price of the underlying security. In the context of Bitcoin/CivKit, it could involve seizing an opportunity by forwarding a HTLC across a Lightning payment path to enter into a trade before publishing the offer on a bulletin board.To understand the issue better, Chris provided a summary of the scenario they discussed. The scenario involves three key players: Mary the Maker, Terry the Taker, and Bob the bulletin board operator. Mary publishes a limit order to buy a derivative, and Bob has the option to execute against Mary's order. If Bob doesn't want to execute, he relays the order to Terry and other subscribers to Bob's market. Terry then has the option to execute a trade against Mary's order. If Terry decides not to execute, Mary's order sits on the bulletin board.Antoine agrees with Chris that this may not be a big concern. If Bob can collect outsized profits as the bulletin board operator, Terry will eventually move to other markets because Bob is only relaying what he perceives to be unprofitable orders. From Mary's perspective, she is happy because her order got executed at the price she specified. However, Terry is the one who loses out in this model, as it resembles more of a brokerage rather than an exchange market structure. Antoine suggests that Terry should open his own brokerage and compete on quoting prices with Bob. By comparing metrics like execution quality, Bob and Terry can draw more market activity by providing better prices.The conversation then shifts to the topic of front-running resistance in a peer-to-peer marketplace. Antoine proposes two security paradigms to mitigate front-running. The first involves duplicating the announcement of offers to multiple concurrent boards operated by independent identities and monitoring the latency. Latency anomalies can be flagged by a watchtower-like infrastructure, and if repeated anomalies occur, a maker can disqualify the misbehaving board from future announcements. However, this paradigm has some limitations and may still allow for exploitation by boards.The second paradigm involves running bulletin boards as a federation using Honey Badger BFT or similar techniques. In this approach, incoming board offers become consensus items that must be announced to all federation members before publication. The federation members earn income as a group by following consensus rules. This approach could level the playing field for all market participants.Antoine acknowledges that there may be other security paradigms to mitigate front-running and information asymmetries, but these are the ones he has considered so far. He believes that the CivKit framework provides a flexible foundation for a peer-to-peer marketplace, where parameters like propagation latency monitoring and federation set and rules can be adjusted to adapt to different types of trades and market participants' tolerance.In conclusion, Antoine expresses his satisfaction with the idea of mass front-running on the board, as it indicates active participants and liquidity in the market. He emphasizes that finding what products people are interested in trading and providing them with a good user experience is more important, as everything else will fall into place after that.Moving on to another development, a group including Nicholas Gregory and Ray Youssef is developing a new peer-to-peer market system that aims to enable censorship-resistant and permissionless global trading. The design combines the Nostr architecture with Lightning onion routing infrastructure to grant a high level of confidentiality to market participants. The market boards are Nostr relays with a Lightning gateway, each operating autonomously and in competition.Trades in this system are escrowed under Bitcoin Script contracts, relying on moderations and know your peer oracles for adjudication. To enable scoring of trades, counterparties, and services operators, the introduction of a Web-of-Stakes is proposed, which assigns an economic weight to each market entity based on the Bitcoin UTXO set. This reputation paradigm can be combined with decentralized identifiers from Web-of-Trust techniques.To incentivize service operators, a consistent framework is suggested through privacy-preserving credentials backed by Bitcoin payments. This framework follows the principles of IETF's Privacy Pass. The whitepaper provides a detailed analysis of the system's architecture and plans to release code and modules gradually, building on top of the Lightning Dev Kit and Nostr libraries.The developers aim to collaborate with the community to standardize libraries and ensure interoperability between clients. They welcome feedback and emphasize their adherence to the best Bitcoin open-source and decentralized standards established by Bitcoin Core.
